Josh McBroom
User-Focused Full-Stack Developer

About

I'm a user-focused Full-Stack Developer who uses my background in customer service and hospitality to make every customer's experience awesome. Over the past few years, I've begun transitioning from the customer service industry into the technology sector.

Along the way, I've learned a ton by failing at launching two businesses, before successfully organizing Seattle's first hackathon for cannabis technology. I'm currently seeking a junior developer position where I can use my natural strengths to help better solve customers' problems.

Technologies I use:


Projects

Contact Me


Around the Web

Copyright © Josh McBroom 2016

MagicButton

The project I'm currently working on is [Magic Button][link]{:target="_blank"}, a one-click meal planning and grocery-list-making app. List your favorite meals and add the ingredients you need for them - after that, planning your week's meals and making the grocery list is as easy as one click! Technologies used: JavaScript, HTML, CSS, Bootstrap, MongoDB, Express, Angular, and Node [link]: https://github.com/dropTheNon/magicButton
  • Category: MEAN
  • Date: August 2016

Ensemble News

As part of a one-day team hackathon, my team built [Ensemble News][link]{:target="_blank"} - search for any topic and receive relevant articles from numerous publications. For this project I served as full-stack developer. Technologies used: JavaScript, MongoDB, Express, Angular, Node, and APIs [link]: http://ensemble-news.herokuapp.com
  • Category: Hackathon
  • Date: July 2016

Squeaky Wheel

SqueakyWheel was a group class project. Our group created the digital version of a complaint box - users can create a complaint about a company or product, or “upvote” an existing complaint, and we send an email or tweet to the appropriate party on their behalf. For this project I served as our Project Manager, Git Master, and did back-end development.

Technologies used: Ruby on Rails, PostgreSQL, D3.js, Cloudinary

  • Category: Ruby on Rails
  • Date: July 2016

CannaVis

I created CannaVis - a tool that helps cannabis businesses make better decisions through better understanding of data - to utilize data visualization and begin learning D3.

Technologies used: JavaScript, HTML, CSS, D3.js

  • Category: D3
  • Date: July 2016

GrassRoots Hackathon

In May of 2015, I organized Seattle’s first hackathon for cannabis technology, GrassRoots Hackathon. As the founder and lead organizer, I was responsible for the entirety of the event, including securing sponsors and venue, finding mentors and judges, and everything else that goes into organizing a weekend-long event.

Technologies used: WordPress, BrownPaperTickets.com, PayPal, Google Drive, Google Hangouts

  • Category: Event
  • Date: May 2015

Gropher

Gropher was a side project started at Startup Weekend. Gropher was an on-demand grocery-shopping app, letting users select a store, order ahead, and pick up their order without leaving their car. For this project, I served as project manager and business developer.

Technologies used: HTML, CSS, JavaScript

  • Category: Hackathon
  • Date: April 2014
